metadata.title: Surface Hydrography - PWS, Copper River
metadata.description: Data Type: Freshwater Systems;  This data layer is a composite of polygonal surface hydrography data, derived from several different sources at differing scales, organized by 1:250,000 scale USGS quadrangles, and included as a merged layer. This layer covers the Prince William Sound - Copper River ecosystem and includes information on lakes, wide river channels, marine areas, and glaciers. The most detailed stream and lake coverages for Prince William Sound are taken largely from the Chugach National Forest's Channel Type Database (for line features) and the Timber Type Database (for polygonal features).  Pacific GIS filled gaps in these datasets with stream and lake information from the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR) Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Database. Pacific GIS drew stream data for areas outside of Prince William Sound largely from Alaska DNR's Alaska Land and Resource Mapping  (ALARM) database. This dataset is considerably coarser than the hydrography information for Prince William Sound. All stream data, except those obtained from the Chugach National Forest Channel Type Database, include information on presence of anadromous fish, although this information is variable in age and not documented as to source. Pacific GIS merged these datasets used for this quad-by-quad layer to develop a composite surface hydrography layer for the Prince William Sound - Copper River basin ecosystem (hydro_pl in the ecosystem directory). A related data layer, river250 contains stream data for the greater PWS - Copper River ecosystem.

metadata.title: Arctic Ice-Ocean Modeling with and without Climate Restoring
metadata.description:
A coupled iceﾖmixed layerﾖocean model is constructed for the Arctic
     Ocean, the Barents Sea, and the GreenlandﾖIcelandﾖNorwegian Sea. The
     model is used to address Arctic numerical modeling with and without climate
     restoring. The model without climate restoring reproduces basic observed
     features of the Arctic iceﾖocean circulation. The simulated oceanic
     processes adjust to the surface and lateral fluxes and transport heat and
     mass in a way that achieves a rough salt and heat balance in the Arctic in the
     integration period of seven decades. The main deficiency of the model is its
     prediction of unrealistically high salinity in the central Arctic, which tends to
     weaken the ocean currents.

       The introduction of corrective salinity and temperature restoring terms has
     a significant impact on prediction of the iceﾖocean circulation in the Arctic.
     The impact results from a chain reaction. First, the restoring terms change
     the salinity and thermal states in the oceanic mixed layer and below. The
     altered density structure, in turn, influences the ocean circulation by altering
     the oceanﾒs dynamic and thermodynamic processes. The ocean circulation
     then affects ice motion and ice thickness by altering the dynamics and
     thermodynamics of the ice. Restoring only ocean salinity induces a heat
     surplus or deficit, which causes the oceanic thermal state to drift away from
     the Climatology. This is also the case with restoring both salinity and
     temperature in the upper ocean. Only restoring salinity and temperature in
     the deeper ocean is likely to avoid climate drift in the Arctic.

       This paper points out the problems of using models without climate
     restoring and the consequences of using models with climate restoring for
     Arctic iceﾖocean modeling. It stresses the need to use a realistic
     representation of surface fluxes in order to improve prognostic simulations. It
     also stresses the importance of oceanic processes such as connective
     overturning and vertical advection both in the Arctic and in the adjacent
     oceans. If these processes are not reasonably represented, the models can
     predict over warm intermediate layers in the Arctic and an excessive heat
     influx at Fram Strait, causing the Arctic ice pack to possibly shrink gradually,
     a scenario global climate models should avoid.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report the Arctic IceﾖOcean Modeling with and without Climate Restoring

metadata.title: Moose Survey Data  - CNF
metadata.description: Data Type: Mammals;   Moose survey data provides population data for the Eastern and western Copper River Delta, Prince William Sound, and Eastern Kenai Peninsula. Aerial surveys were flown in a Piper PA-18 aircraft in late November 1994 - January 1995. moose habitat was searched at 1.4-2.2 minutes per square mile. Sex and age ratio estimates were obtained from data collected prior to mid-December. Total numbers in most populations were estimated based on densities observed during aerial surveys, percentage of wintering habitat surveyed, and quality of survey conditions. When survey conditions were not complete, population estimates were based on historical trends. Purpose of this data is to monitor moose populations on the Chugach National Forest lands and to use moose as an indicator species of diversity and habitat health.

metadata.title: The Annual Mean Transport in Puget Sound
metadata.description:
Puget Sound is modeled as a branched system of two-layered advective reaches separated by mixing zones. Fresh water and salt provide
convenient tracers to calculate the annual mean layer transports. The technique utilizes historical records (1951-1956) of runoff and salinity
which are analyzed with the aid of modern (principally 1970's) current meter records to provide the appropriate mass conserving
landward- and seaward-flowing layer salinities for each reach. This is the first time that the long-term transports have been estimated
simultaneously for the entire Strait of Juan de Fuca/Puget Sound system. With few exceptions the inferred transports agree well with
estimates derived from scattered, shorter duration current observations. Uncertainties in the transports are estimated from uncertainties in
the runoff, velocity profiles and salinities. The results provide the basis for future computations of refluxing and the steady state tracer
concentrations and ages in the Sound.

metadata.title: Tsunami Runup Distribution Generated by the July 12, 1993, Hokkaido-Nansei-Oki earthquake
metadata.description:
The Hokkaido-Nansei-Oki earthquake produced one of the largest tsunamis in Japan's history. Tsunami vertical runup measurements varied between 15 and 30 m
over a 20-km portion of the southern part of Okushiri Island with several 10-m values on the northern portion of the Island. Along the west coast of Hokkaido, no
survey values exceeded 10 m, but damage was extensive at several coastal towns. Given the sudden onset of the tsunami and its high energy, it is amazing that more
people were not killed. We also observed that the seawall at Aonae was effective in reducing runup amplitudes.

metadata.title: Modeling Sea Ice as a Granular Material, Including  the Dilatancy Effect
metadata.description:
A dynamic sea ice model based on granular material rheology is
     presented. The sea ice model is coupled to both a mixed layer ocean model
     and a one-layer thermodynamic atmospheric model, which allows for an ice
     albedo feedback. Land is represented by a 6-m thick layer with a constant
     base temperature. A 10-year integration including both thermodynamic and
     dynamic effects and incorporating prescribed climatological wind stress and
     ocean current data was performed in order for the model to reach a stable
     periodic seasonal cycle. The commonly observed lead complexes, along
     which sliding and opening of adjacent ice floes occur in the Arctic sea ice
     cover, are well reproduced in this simulation. In particular, shear lines
     extending from the western Canadian Archipelago toward the central Arctic,
     often observed in winter satellite images, are present. The ice edge is well
     positioned both in winter and summer using this thermodynamically coupled
     oceanﾖiceﾖatmosphere model. The results also yield a sea ice circulation and
     thickness distribution over the Arctic, which are in good agreement with
     observations. The model also produces an increase in ice formation
     associated with the dilatation of the ice medium along sliding lines. In this
     model, incident energy absorbed by the ocean melts ice laterally and warms
     the mixed layer, causing a smaller ice retreat in the summer. This cures a
     problem common to many existing thermodynamicﾖdynamic sea ice models
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the modeling Sea Ice as a Granular Material, Including  the Dilatancy Effect

metadata.title: Copper River - Local Database
metadata.description: Data Type: Multi-Resources;   Local data base was compiled in support of the Department of Natural Resources Copper River Basin Area Plan. This database was compiled through a contract to Arctic Geo Resources (AGRA) by the State of Alaska DGGS, Resource Analysis Section. The database contains data of two scales, 1:250,000 and 1:63360. Areas of high interest mapped at the 1:63360 scale, are primarily state owned lands in the central basin and along major roads. Geology and vegetation (minimum unit 20-40 acres) are the main themes mapped at the detailed scale. Other data topics, trails, roads, recreation use, political and administrative use, oil and gas resources, minerals, infrastructure, hydrology, historical and archeological sites, general geology, and geologic constraints. Other statewide coverages were used to supplement this data set. Soils were used from the area 612 Soil Survey conducted by Soil Conservation Service. Portions of this dataset have been extracted and reformatted for use in the Copper River Basin GIS Database developed by Ecotrust/Pacific GIS, in 1995.

metadata.title: Ecological Inventories Chugach National Forest
metadata.description: Data Type: Multi-Resources;   The Chugach National Forest has for the past five years been working on various multi-resource inventories across National Forest lands in the Chugach National Forest. These inventories are in various stages of completion. An integrated ecological inventory to include National Forest lands on the Kenai Peninsula is presently underway. Data will be automated in GIS format for use in the Chugach Forest Plan revision process. This data set's intended use is for baseline data support for project oriented projects being conducted within the forest on the Kenai Peninsula. The Copper River Delta integrated inventory includes landform, soils, and vegetation communities is almost complete. It will be entered into the Chugach GIS system in ARC/INFO format. A general lands system inventory scheduled for completion in 1995 for the entire forest is presently being conducted and includes landforms and sub group soils mapping.

metadata.title: Graphical Resource Database

creators.name: Alyeska Pipeline Service Company contracted to EMCOM Alaska Inc.

metadata.description: Database: Multi-Resources;  The Ship Escort/Response Vessel System (SERVS) of Alyeska Pipeline Service Company (Alyeska) is currently undertaking a major expansion and update of its environmental computer database for Prince William Sound and adjoining areas on the south-central coast of Alaska. The software, called the Graphical Resource Database (GRD), is part of Alyeska's commitment to the Prince William Sound Tanker Oil Discharge Prevention and Contingency Plan. The GRD consists of layers of coastal resource digital data records (such as seabird colony sites and sea otter concentration areas) that are linked to points, lines, or polygons depicting animal distributions on computer-generated maps. The expansion and update effort is coordinated by a committee consisting of representatives from federal and state natural resource trustee agencies, citizens oversight groups, Alyeska, and oil shipping companies. The data collection and checking process is conducted in accordance with written standard operating procedures. Data are gathered from the trustee agencies, compiled into Microsoft Excel spreadsheets, and verified using quality control/quality assurance procedures. The spreadsheets are then loaded into a commercially available mapping program, MapInfo , which serves as an intermediate graphical data management tool. The data are transferred from MapInfo to the GRD using FORTRAN programs. Data is available to federal and state agencies for oil spill planning and response.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Create a sensitive coastal resource database that will be held in common and mutually accessible by government trustee agencies and industry.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: The database is the property of Alyeska. It distributes it to wildlife trustee agencies for oil spill response and planning.

metadata.title: Sea Database - Prince Williams Sound
metadata.description: Database: Multi-Resources;   The SEA database includes SEA measurements for Prince William Sound studies, historical archives for biological, oceanographic and weather datasets for PWS. Currents are measured by the SEAOCEAN project using an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP). Advanced Visualization System software is used to allow the user to zoom and navigate interactively through the sound to examine three-dimensional structure of the data. The SEADATA project is using this system to display data collected by multiple SEA groups. Thus allowing distribution of nutrients, plankton, fish and predators to be viewed in relation to one another and to physical conditions such as salinity and current velocity. This system allows users to understand more quickly data from measurements, model simulations and database searches.

metadata.title: Properties of the Arctic 2-Meter Air Temperature Field for 1979 to the Present Derived from a New Gridded Dataset
metadata.description:
This paper discusses the behavior of the Arctic Ocean surface air
     temperature field for 1979ﾖ93. Temperatures are derived from a new
     gridded 6-h, 2-m air temperature dataset called POLES. These gridded air
     temperatures are estimated from optimal interpolation of temperature inputs
     from drifting buoys, manned Soviet North Pole (NP) drifting ice stations,
     coastal land weather stations, and ship reports. In processing the POLES
     data, the winter and summer properties of the mean NP temperatures are
     used to discard inaccurate or snow-covered buoys and to remove a summer
     warm bias. Comparison of the POLES and specific NP temperatures shows
     that the POLES temperature behaves well and gives better results than other
     gridded temperature datasets. Maps of the mean seasonal temperatures give
     realistic results consistent with other published estimates, and plots of the
     summer advance and retreat of the 0°C isotherm show the expected
     asymmetry between advance and retreat associated with the open water
     formation adjacent to the coasts. Also, comparison of the regional POLES
     observations of the annual onset of melt and freeze with published estimates
     derived from visible and passive microwave satellite data gives realistic
     results. However, problems with the dataset arise in the post-1991 period
     from the termination of the NP stations and a reduction in the number of
     Siberian and Alaskan weather stations. In spite of these problems, the paper
     shows that the POLES dataset provides an improved air temperature field
     for use in numerical sea ice models and for comparison with satellite
     datasets.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the properties of the Arctic 2-Meter Air Temperature Field for 1979 to the Present Derived from a New Gridded Dataset

metadata.title: Bathymetric Contours
metadata.description: Data Type: Ocean/Coasts ;   This layer contains bathymetric contours (20m interval) for the Exxon Valdez oil spill area as distributed by the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR). The Alaska DNR data is based primarily on National Ocean Service (NOS) data. NOS publishes digital bathymetric data in two forms: raw depths of all soundings from included bathymetric surveys, and "gridded" data (a summarization of the raw data information). Gridded data is a summarization of raw NOS data information and includes the mean, maximum, and minimum depths recorded in each cell in a 15 second latitude by 15 second longitude grid. The Alaska DNR augmented the gridded data with information from NOAA nautical charts and converted it to bathymetric contours (interval = 20 m). Please see documentation for bath_pl and bath_pt for related databases.

metadata.title: State Coastline - EVOS Database
metadata.description: Data Type: Ocean/Coasts ;   The data set consists of digitized shoreline data (i.e., salt water/land interface) for three geographic areas of Prince William Sound (PWS), Cook Inlet/Kenai Peninsula (CIK) and Kodiak/Alaska Peninsula (KAP). The shoreline data used to cover the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill (EVOS) region is currently shared and held in common by the involved State and Federal agencies. This transaction occurred early on after the spill so subsequent data related to the coastline would be consistently defined. The shoreline data covering PWS was cooperatively sourced from USFS, Chugach Forest Office. The coverage was digitized from the most currently available 1:63360 USGS map series, with the exception of USFS Big Islands Management Area (Green, Montague, Hawkins, Hinchinbrook, and associated satellite islands. The coastline for the Big Islands was derived from Chugach National Forest 1:31,680 timber type maps. These maps were created from 1:15,840 1974 USFS photography. Coastline was determined at mean high tideline. Green Island, Little Green Island and satellite islands were replaced using 1988 USGS 1:63,360 maps. CIK shoreline was purchased from ComRim Systems Inc. at the same scale using USGS basemaps. Information on thousands of small islands and rock outcrops was taken from the Exxon shoreline for PWS and CIK.

metadata.title: Regional Variation of Winter Temperatures in the Arctic
metadata.description:
The surface temperature field in the Arctic winter is primarily controlled by
     downward longwave radiation, which is determined by local atmospheric
     temperature and humidity profiles and the presence of clouds. The authors
     show that regional differences in the atmospheric thermal energy budget are
     related to the tropospheric circulation in the Arctic. Data sources include
     several gridded meteorological datasets and surface and rawinsonde
     observational data. Four independent climatologies of mean January surface
     temperature show consistent spatial patterns: coldest temperatures in the
     western Arctic north of Canada and warmer regions in the Chukchi,
     Greenland, and Barents Seas. Data from the five winters of 1986ﾖ90
     illustrate the coupling between the surface temperature, the downward
     longwave radioactive fields, and the tropospheric temperature and humidity
     fields, with monthly surfaceﾖupper-air correlation on the order of 0.6.
     Upper-level circulation patterns reveal features similar to the surface
     temperature fields, notably a persistent low center located over northern
     Canada; the cyclonic flow around the low is a tropospheric extension of the
     polar vortex. Colder and drier conditions are maintained within the vortex
     and communicated to the surface through radioactive processes. The polar
     vortex also steers transient weather systems, the most important mechanism
     for horizontal heat transport, into the eastern Arctic, which results in as much
     as 25 W m2 more heat flux into the eastern Arctic than the western Arctic.
     A reason for the colder temperatures in the western Arctic is that the polar
     vortex tends to be situated downstream of the northern Rocky Mountains;
     this preferred location is related to orographic forcing of planetary waves.
     Monthly and interannual variability of winter temperatures is conditioned by
     the interaction of the Arctic and midlatitude circulations through the strength
     and position of the polar vortex.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the regional Variation of Winter Temperatures in the Arctic

metadata.title: Role of the Bering Strait in Controlling North Atlantic Ocean Circulation and Climate
metadata.description:
Recent climate records from ice cores and deep-sea sediments suggest that
        there has been considerable climate variability in the North Atlantic region
        over the past 250,000 years. Much of this variability may be linked to changes
        in thermohaline circulation in the North Atlantic ocean. Model studies have
        demonstrated that changes in the flux of fresh water to the ocean, resulting
        from changes in atmospheric transport or the waxing and waning of ice sheets,
        can have a significant effect on the thermohaline circulation. The authors
        present model simulations showing that increased flow of fresher North Pacific
        water through the Bering Strait into the northern North Atlantic can also
        effect the thermohaline circulation, by suppressing North Atlantic Deep Water
        formation; however, decreased flow does not necessarily cause deep-water
        formation to begin again. In the model, flow through the Bering Strait
        depends on ecstatic sea level and the salinity difference between the North
        Atlantic and North Pacific oceans. The authors suggest that a higher sea level
        during the last interglacial period, leading to greater flow through the Bering
        Strait, may have made the North Atlantic thermohaline circulation more
        sensitive than it is at present to fluctuations in the hydrological cycle, which
        may explain recent observations indicating that climate variability was greater
        then than it is today.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the role of the Bering Strait in controlling North Atlantic Ocean circulation and climate

metadata.title: Copper River Basin Subsistence

creators.name: AHTNA/Copper River Native Association contract to Institute

metadata.description: Data Type: Subsistence/Traditional Knowledge;   This dataset is a multi-layered subsistence database pulling together existing data sources. Layers include drainage, hypsography, supplemental hypsography, political boundaries and ocean net, populated places, park boundaries, land selection status, 1:250,000 USGS Quadrangle boundaries,  Ahtna Clan boundaries, native corporation boundaries, traditional use, Ahtna place names, Native routes, registered traplines, trapping areas, woodcutting areas4/88, hunting areas, fishing, boating, and camping areas, wood cutting areas 3/86, hunting areas 3/86, subsistence hunt areas for large mammals, Game Management Units ADF&G. Intended use of information is to aid CRNA meet criteria to establish permanent rights for Ahtna shareholders to pursue subsistence activities in Wrangell St. Elias National Park and preserve and protect Ahtna subsistence use areas and resources from urban competition. This database is part of a cooperative agreement with NPS and BLM to develop information relevant to Customary and Traditional Use determinations, the establishment of Residential Zones for subsistence use in the park and to establish a roster of eligible subsistence users in the Park/Preserve under section 1344 of ANILCA. Copies of the final dataset will reside at BLM, Ahtna, Copper River Native Assoc., and NPS. Some layers of this dataset have been extracted as separate records in the metadata database as they represent data that was automated as a result of this dataset compilation and are new electronic products. See metadata record #118,119,116, and 117.

metadata.title: Copper River Delta Community Classification Field Plots
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  The database consists plot information collected in 1993-94 by The Alaska Natural Heritage program under a cooperative agreement with the Chugach National Forest to develop a hierarchical classification of community types, describe the successional plant community sequences, and landcover associations for the Copper River Delta. Plot information was collected by trained field crews and georeferenced to 1:63,360 and 1:60,000 CIR air photos. 286 plots were used to create the classification. These data points reside in a paradox database format. The intended use of these data were used to develop and support the community type classification for the area for use by the U.S.  Forest Service. These data have not been put in a GIS system but are GIS ready.

metadata.title: DMSP F8 SSM/I Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration Grids

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F8 SSM/I Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration for the Polar Regions 
for July 1987 through December 1991 were produced by NSIDC using the daily
sea ice concentration grids which were generated using the NASATEAM 
algorithm (Cavalieri, et al. 1986, JGR 91(C1), p. 975-994) and distributed
on CD-ROM by NSIDC.  The monthly sea ice grids are available on request
via ftp (see access instructions below), and may eventually be distributed 
on CD-ROM with other SSM/I products.  The monthly sea ice grids can be used 
as a mask to block out ice-covered areas for various applications.  To 
accommodate as many  potential applications as possible, the monthly averaged 
ice extent was delineated using four concentration values (0%, 5%, 10%, and 
15%) for the minimum concentrations included in the averages.  The grids are 
8-bit raster images containing 448 lines of 304 pixels (304x by 448y) for the
northern hemisphere and 332 lines of 316 pixels (316x by 332y) for the
southern.  IDL procedures were used to calculate monthly averages from the
daily-averaged SSM/I grids.  The data were then put into Hierarchical Data
Format (HDF).  Utilities to read and manipulate HDF data are available via
ftp from the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA).  The
NCSA ftp server address is ftp.ncsa.uiuc.edu; help is available from
helphdf@ncsa.uiuc.edu.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the  Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration for the Polar Regions 
for July 1987 through December 1991 were produced by NSIDC using the daily
sea ice concentration grids which were generated using the NASATEAM 
algorithm (Cavalieri, et al. 1986, JGR 91(C1), p. 975-994) and distributed
on CD-ROM by NSIDC.

metadata.title: Land Cover/Vegetation - PWS, Copper River
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  This data layer is a composite of vegetation and land cover data encompassing all of Prince William Sound and the Copper River drainage and eastern portions of the Kenai Peninsula. Original data sources include the Chugach National Forest Timber Type database, Interim Land Cover Program and Copper River Land Cover images from USGS EROS Alaska Field Office, and the Alaska Land and Resource Mapping System (ALARM) from the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR). All of the original datasets were generalized; merged, and classified according to the Alaska Vegetation Classification, resulting in a generalized layer that broadly characterizes vegetation patterns throughout the area. Characteristics of the original data bases are outlined below; the data sets used to create this composite vegetation layer are documented separately The Chugach NF Timber Type database is a timber oriented vegetation layer based on interpretation of aerial photography. It is the most detailed digital vegetation information available for substantial areas within the greater Prince William Sound ecosystem. The database contains detailed information about timbered areas including species composition, stand density, stocking levels, stand class size, and volume. Many of these timber-oriented descriptions can be useful as surrogates for important ecological variables such as structural information about a given stand. The database also contains less detailed information on non- forest vegetation and cover types. Both the Interim Land Cover and Copper River Land Cover datasets are based on Landsat Multispectral Sensor (MSS) satellite imagery with an original resolution of 80 meters. The Copper River Land Cover data contains more detailed information on shrub and herbaceous communities than the Interim Land Cover Program and the Chugach NF Timber Type datasets. The ALARM datasets are based in part on interpretation of Landsat MSS imagery and aerial photography but have been generalized considerably; the minimum mapping unit used in the ALARM program was 640 acres. Each dataset used to compile this data layer uses a different vegetation classification scheme, a result of intended use and method of data automation. All but the Chugach National Forest Timber Type database use modifications of the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme (Viereck et al. 1992). Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the vegetation types in each data source to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem.

metadata.title: DMSP F8 Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions on CD-ROM

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F8 SSM/I ice concentrations are daily first-year, multi-year, and 
total ice, 25 x 25 km polar stereographic grids, north and south polar 
regions, output from two algorithms: NASA Team algorithm (Cavalieri et 
al. 1986; 1994 in prep.), and Comiso "Bootstrap" algorithm (Comiso 1994
in prep.).  Input data are orbital antenna temperatures processed to gridded 
brightness temperatures.  Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) 
F8 platform carried this first functional Special Sensor Microwave/Imager 
instrument, a linearly-polarized passive microwave radiometric system at 
85.5 GHz V/H, 37.0 GHz V/H, 22.2 GHz V, 19.3 GHz V/H. Two CD-ROMs contain 
all F8 SSM/I ice concentrations, 9 July 1987 - 31 December 1991 (NP 
files = 137202 bytes, SP files = 105922 bytes, in HDF.  Software to read
and manipulate HDF are available from National Center for Supercomputing
Applications (NCSA) via ftp (ftp.ncsa.uiuc.edu). Other public domain and 
commercial software packages, such as IDL, are available that can read and 
manipulate HDF.  SSM/I CD-ROMs are presently being distributed at no charge, 
with first priority for the NASA and NASA-funded research communities.  
This distribution policy is subject to change without notice; please inquire.  
NSIDC is processing DMSP F11 SSM/I in the same grid/projection.

The primary archive and distribution source for DMSP SSM/I swath
(orbital) data (level 1b) is NOAA/NESDIS Satellite Data Services Division,
Princeton Executive Square, Room 100, Washington, DC 20233; telephone
301-763-8402.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the DMSP F8 Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions on CD-ROM

metadata.title: Vegetation CNF Forest Timber Type
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  Pacific GIS compiled several different vegetation datasets organized by 1:250,000 scale USGS quadrangles to cover the Prince William Sound - Copper River ecosystem. The Chugach National Forest Timber Type database is a timber oriented vegetation layer based on interpretation of aerial photography. It is the most detailed digital vegetation information available for substantial areas within the greater Prince William Sound ecosystem. The database contains detailed information about timbered areas including species composition, stand density, stocking levels, stand class size, and volume. Many of these timber- oriented descriptions can be useful as surrogates for important ecological variables such as structural information about a given stand. The database also contains less detailed information on non-forest vegetation and cover types.

metadata.title: Vegetation Developed Using ALARM (Alaska Land And Resources Mapping Program)

creators.name: Service, U.S. Natural Resource Conservation Service formerly Soil Conservation

metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  Vegetation developed using Alaska Land And Resources Mapping Program (ALARM). Pacific GIS used several different full resolution vegetation datasets organized by 1:250,000 scale USGS quadrangles to cover the Prince William Sound - Copper River ecosystem. This data set, developed by the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR) was created to assist in region wide planning efforts. Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the original vegetation codes to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem for various sources of vegetation data. This common classification is included along with the original classification.

metadata.title: Vegetation (Interim Land Cover)
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  Pacific GIS used several different full resolution vegetation datasets organized by 1:250,000 scale USGS quadrangles to cover the Prince William Sound - Copper River ecosystem. The USGS EROS Alaska Field Office developed the Interim Land Cover dataset which is based on Landsat Multispectral Sensor (MSS) satellite imagery with an original resolution of 80 meters. Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the interim land cover vegetation types to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem for various sources of vegetation data. This common classification has been added to the original classification information.

metadata.title: Wrangell-Elias Vegetation Ground Plots
metadata.description: Data Type:  ;  Spatially referenced vegetation ground plot data collected over a 12 year period throughout Wrangell St. Elias National Park. Vegetative species information and related canopy cover data was collected from ground plots. Plots have been classified using the Alaska Vegetation Classification Scheme. All plots have been referenced on Alaska High Altitude Color Infrared photography at 1:63360 scale. The collection of this data was supported by the regional fire program to provide ground information as to fire fuels for Wrangell St. Elias National Park. These plots have been used for other applications as supportive information for landcover mapping, habitat interpretations, general vegetation knowledge, etc. A Vegetation Survey effort has been underway at the park for approximately 12 years and recently has expanded. Rare plant surveys are currently being conducted as well. All collection points are now spatially referenced with GPS systems.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Unknown

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: Unknown

Use constraints: Data is spatially located on color infrared aerial photography and has not yet been automated in a GIS system. Attribute data has been automated by Wrangell St. Elias National Park in database management system.

metadata.title: Coastal Bathymetry of the Bering, Chukchi and Beaufort Seas
metadata.description: Bathymetric contours were generated from soundings collected by National Ocean Service vessels from 1900 to 1971. The 1:250,000 maps are available for U.S. coastal waters. Bathymetric contours are in meters, with 10 meter intervals out to 200 m, supplemented by 2 m contours. Beyond 200 m, contours are at 50 m intervals to maximum depth. The GIS database derived from these maps includes the Bering, Chukchi, and Beaufort Seas in western and northern Alaska. Approximately 100 maps.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: The Bathymetric Map series was developed to provide detailed contours of underwater features. The maps serve as a basic tool for performing scientific, engineering, marine geophysical, and marine environmental studies. The maps were not intended to be used for navigation.

metadata.title: Terrain Units of the Arctic Refuge Coastal Plain (Walker, D.A.)
metadata.description: Data Type: TERRAIN UNITS;   This dataset is a digital depiction of the Walker, 1983 terrain unit mapping of the Arctic Refuge coastal plain. Five terrain unit types were described for a major portion of the 1002 study area of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Each terrain unit delineates a combined characterization of dominant soils, landforms and vegetation types. Portions of the map were extended geographically, using LANDSAT TM interpretations and aerial photography. Two original terrain classes, Floodplains and Hilly Coastal plain, were further subdivided into east and west for USFWS purposes of this dataset.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: These data provide a depiction of terrain units that combine a characterization of soils, landforms, and vegetation. These data were integrated as ancillary data in the spectral analysis of the 1994 USFWS 1002 TM LANDSAT Landcover map for the 1002 study area. This dataset is useful for a variety of resource applications, resource evaluations and habitat analysis.

metadata.title: Response of Sea Ice Drift to Wind Forcing on the Northeastern Newfoundland Shelf
metadata.description:
Observations of sea ice drift obtained with satellite-tracked ice beacons in
     March-April of 1988 and 1989 have been used to examine the response of
     sea ice drift to wind forcing over the northern Newfoundland continental shelf.
     The short-term (5-20 days) response of sea ice drift ranges from 2.6 to 5.4%
     of the local wind over much of the inner continental shelf, which is comparable
     to that in the Bering Sea and the Antarctic but larger than that in Arctic. Sea
     ice drifts to the right of the local wind, at angles ranging from 10 degree to 63
     degree . The response to wind forcing is largest near the ice edge, both over
     the middle portions of the shelf and along the southern margins of the seasonal
     ice zone and during strong and steady wind of several days' duration. The
     large wind-driven response of ice drift observed in this study, in comparison
     with the Arctic, may result from (1) reduced levels of internal ice stress
     associated with the generally thin ice cover and lower areal concentration of
     sea ice, (2) large atmospheric drag coefficients associated with the small ice
     floes in areas of comparatively higher ice concentration, and (3) smooth ice
     bottom caused by melting. In nearshore areas the ice to wind coupling is
     reduced owing to larger internal ice stresses experienced locally due to ice
     pileup.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the response of sea ice drift to wind forcing on the northeastern Newfoundland shelf

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned

metadata.title: DMSP-F11 Monthly Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F11 monthly averaged sea ice concentration grids in the polar 
stereographic projection are produced based on daily sea ice concentration 
grids generated using the NASA Team algorithm. Processing is continuous 
beginning 3 December 1991,  and continues the series begun with F8 monthly 
averaged data. Although a high degree of correlation exists between F8 and F11 
data (Abdalati et al. 1995), regression coefficients (NSIDC 1995) have been 
applied in deriving F11 daily ice concentrations, which form the basis for 
this data set. Monthly averaged data files contain ice concentration in 
percent ranging from 0% to 100%. Then, ice concentrations are delineated 
using 0%, 5%, 10% and 15% as the minimum concentrations included in the 
averages (e.g.: a 5% cutoff sets all data values between 1% and 5% to 0%). 
These four thresholds accommodate as many potential applications as possible. 
Grids are 8-bit raster images stored in HDF.  Data in compressed tar files are 
distributed via ftp, on sidads.colorado.edu (IP address 128.138.135.20).
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the Monthly Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

metadata.title: Digital Chart of the World (DCW)
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps;   The DCW is a vector basemap of the world at a scale of 1:1,000,000 developed by ESRI for ARC/INFO. The database consists of geographic, attribute, and textual data that is divides the world into 2,094 fifteen by fifteen degree tiles that are each subdivided into five by five degree tiles. Over 200 attributes are included in 17 thematic layers. The DCW is 1.7 gigabytes in size distributed on four CD-ROMs. There is an Alaska module to this dataset that is available, that consists of all available layers covering only the State of Alaska. Grid-arendal Global Resource Information database sponsored by the United Nations have produced a similar subsection of the DCW for the polar region of the world, north of 45 degree latitude. The potential user will need to consult the DCW data dictionary for a complete review of database contents.
metadata.notes:

metadata.title: NOAA Nautical Charts
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ;Conventional flat nautical charts for navigation are assigned to different scale groups. Harbor Charts are 1:50,000 or larger and are intended navigation and anchorage. Coast Charts are 1:50,000 to 1:150,000 and are intended for coastwise navigation inside the offshore reefs and shoals, entering bays and harbors of considerable size, and navigating certain inland waterways. General Charts are 1:150,000 to 1:600,000 and are intended for use when a vessel's course is well offshore, but when its position can be fixed by landmarks, lights, buoys, and characteristic soundings. Nautical charts are in the process of being put into a raster format but are not yet available.

metadata.title: DMSP F11 Special Sensor Microwave Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
Group:  Summary DMSP-F11 daily, total and multi-year sea ice concentration
grids are derived from the SSM/I daily brightness temperatures.  With a
resolution of 25X25 km, these sea ice concentrations are presented as
raster images (HDF raster image sets, RIS) mapped to polar stereographic
projections depicting north and south polar regions. Data are stored in
HDF and packaged in compressed tar format. These ice concentrations
continue the series begun with DMSP-F8 SSM/I coverage, generated using the
NASA Team algorithm. Processing is continuous on the F11 data, beginning 3
December 1991.  The DMSP-F8 and -F11 data demonstrate a high degree of
correlation (Abdalati et al. 1995) although regression coefficients are
applied in the development of F11 ice concentrations in order to maintain
consistency of the data set (NSIDC 1995). Data are available via ftp
(sidads.colorado.edu, IP address 128.138.135.20).
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the Special Sensor Microwave Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

metadata.title: USGS Digital Line Graphs
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ;Digital Line Graph (DLG) data are digital representations of cartographic information. DLG's of topographic and planimetric map features are derived from cartographic source materials using manual and automated digitizing methods. The USGS DLG data is classified as large (1:63,360) intermediate (1:1,000,000), and small (1:2,000,000) scale. Large-scale DLG data are available in nine categories: 1. hypsography, 2. hydrography, 3. vegetative surface cover, 4. non-vegetative features; 5. boundaries; 6. survey control markers; 7. transportation systems 8. manmade features, and 9. US Public Land Survey System, including township, range, and section information. Intermediate-scale DLG's are sold in five categories: 1. Public Land survey, 2. boundaries, 3. transportation 4. hydrography, and 5. hypsography. Small-scale DLG data are sold in three data categories: 1. boundaries; 2. transportation; 3. hydrography. All of these categories are also included on a 1:2,000,000-scale CD-ROM.

metadata.title: USGS Orthophoto Quads
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ; Orthophotos are multicolored, distortion-free, photographic images. Unlike a normal aerial photograph, relief displacement in orthophotos has been removed so that all ground features are displayed in their true ground position. This allows for the direct measurement of distance, areas, angles, and positions. An orthophoto displays features that may be omitted or generalized on maps. They serve a variety of purposes, from interim maps to field references for earth science investigations and analysis. Scale is 1:63,360.

metadata.title: USGS Topographic 1:250,000 Maps
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ; Topographic quadrangle maps at 1:250,000 scale. Terrain is portrayed by contour lines and features such as roads, towns, water areas, and vegetation are shown by map symbols and colors. Dates of maps vary, as most maps were first produced using 1:63,360 maps and aerial photos from the 1940's and 50's, but many maps have been revised to 1980's using aerial photos from the 1970's and 1980's. Contours are at 200 foot intervals. Available as hard-copy paper or mylar maps. It is possible to order a separate, full-scale film negative or positive that shows in black and white all the features printed in a given color on a particular map.

metadata.title: Alaska Coastal Zone Boundaries
metadata.description: The database is a statewide depiction of Alaska's Coastal Zone boundaries, and State of Alaska Department of Fish and Game's associated boundary narratives, updated in 1994. An ARC/INFO AML has been developed that extracts single 1:250,000 USGS quadrangles subsets of data and reprojects it to UTM, allowing use of the data at this scale. Associated ASCII files linked to the INFO attribute file contains legal boundary descriptions for each quadrangle. Data is limited to use at a 1:250,000 scale or smaller and is intended for use at a regional or statewide scale for general planning purposes. Site specific evaluation of CZM boundaries should consult more detailed CZM District data sets existing in manual and some in automated form. The Habitat and Restoration Division of The Alaska Department of Fish and Game has a working copy of this data set that is utilized for the coastal zone permitting process.

metadata.title: Ease-Grid Brightness Temperatures

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
The NOAA/NASA Pathfinder Program SSM/I Level 3 EASE-Grid Brightness 
Temperatures will consist of three series produced on CD-ROM, one series each for the EASE-Grid Northern Hemisphere, Southern Hemisphere and Cylindrical (global) projections. Grids represent spatially interpolated data. The interpolation technique maximizes the radiometric integrity of original brightness temperature values, maintain high spatial and temporal precision, and involve no averaging of original swath data. 

Coverage is global and spans the Pathfinder SSM/I Benchmark period, from
1 August 1987 through 30 November 1988.  Resolution is 25 km for all channels 
and 12.5 km for the 85 GHz channels. There are 18 brightness temperature files 
per day for a given projection (nine each for ascending and descending passes), 
and two (ascending and descending) corresponding time files. Data are contained
in flat binary files, either one image per file consisting of two-dimensional 2-byte integer arrays of brightness temperatures in tenths of Kelvins, or in the case of time files, two-dimensional 1-byte integer arrays consisting of GMT in tenths of hours. 

Data are available as processing is completed, with completion of the data set projected for the end of 1995. Data are available via ftp, on CD-ROM and through the Internet.  Contact NSIDC User Services for information.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the EASE-GRID BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURES

metadata.title: Generalized Land Status
metadata.description: Data Type: Boundaries  ; AKSTATUS is a statewide summary of land ownership in Alaska. It includes the major categories of state, native, and federal holdings. Activity on state land is recorded, by section, in DNR's Land Administration System (LAS). Note that this is not a parcel database. If parts of a single section fall into different ownership categories, then that section will contain multiple codes (see list below). Thus, a section may appear to have conflicting land status due to the resolution of the data (section on/section off), while at the parcel level, there would be no conflicting land status. Detailed maps by township (state status plats) portraying state land ownership are available at the Public Information Center, Department of Natural Resources. Similar maps (master title plats) portraying federal and native land ownership are available at the BLM Public Room, Bureau of Land Management. Please consult these maps for a more precise location of land ownership, and consult the public land record for current land status information.

metadata.title: Recording District Boundaries
metadata.description: Data Type: Boundaries  ; The Recording District Boundary coverage depicts the 34 recording districts established for the administration of the state's system for recording and filing of documents. These boundaries were created by the Alaska Court System as the Alaska Recording Districts Portfolio. The Portfolio dated September 1, 1964, was mandated by Alaska Supreme Court Order No. 12, Amendment No. 13, effective July 1, 1975. Recording district boundaries were originally depicted on 153 United States Geological Survey (USGS) quarter million quadrangle mylar maps, which are maintained by the Anchorage Recording District Office. The recording district boundaries are used to establish the locations in which any recorded public or private document must be recorded and filed. Due to consolidation, the state maintains documents for these 34 recording districts at only 14 filing locations throughout Alaska. All files and records within respective boundaries are maintained at the 14 filing location offices.

metadata.title: Alaska Regional Profiles
metadata.description: A series of six volumes covering Alaska that describe natural and manmade systems. An assembled Planning team made up of resource specialists prepared their respective resource summaries for each of six regions of the state. The sources are a combination of existing and original. Original maps prepared for evaluated resources are currently housed at the Alaska Resource library in the Anchorage Federal Building. General themes include climate, topography, geology, hydrology, soils, biotic communities, cultural resources, land status and services. The intended use of this information was to provide resource information for federal, state, and local planning efforts particularly for land selections under ANILCA. and reflect data current to early 1970's. Volumes 1-Southcentral Region and IV-Southeast Region are applicable to NBS Ecosystem Initiative areas.

metadata.title: Alaska Heritage Resources Survey
metadata.description: Data Type: Cultural Resources;   The Alaska Heritage Resource Survey (AHRS) is an inventory of all reported historic and prehistoric sites within the State of Alaska and is maintained by the office of History and Archeology. This inventory of cultural resources includes objects, structures, buildings, sites, districts, and travel ways with a general provision that they be over 50 years old. To date nearly 15,000 sites have been recorded within Alaska (however, this is probably only a small percentage of the sites which may actually exist but are as yet unreported.) The fundamental use of the AHRS is to protect cultural resource sites from unwanted destruction. Various state, federal and private entities use the inventory for planning and reviewing development projects. The AHRS is primarily a map based system.

metadata.title: USGS Digital Elevation Models 1:63,360
metadata.description: Data Type: Elevation  ; Digital Elevation Model (DEM) data consist of an array of regularly spaced elevations. DEM data in 15-minute units consist of regular arrays of elevations arranged horizontally to the coordinate system of NAD 27. The spacing between elevation along profiles is 2 arc seconds of latitude by 3 arc seconds of longitude. Each profile has 451 elevations. DEM data for 15-minute units correspond to the USGS 15-minute topographic quadrangle map series in Alaska. The unit sizes in Alaska vary depending on the latitude. Unit south of 59 degrees North cover 15x20-minute areas, those between 59 and 62 degrees North cover 15x22.5-minute areas.

metadata.title: Anadromous Streams
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; Data depicts upper and lower extent of Anadromous fish streams throughout Alaska and is updated regularly. ARC/INFO software is used to manage and update data. This dataset is used to produce the Anadromous Waters Catalog for Alaska. Many other Alaska Resource Management agencies are known to use this dataset within their own agencies, utilizing that subset that pertains to the lands under their jurisdiction. The U.S. Forest Service is known to utilize this dataset and the EXXON Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council has as well. Additionally, stream arcs are available for the EVOS area.

metadata.title: Coded Wire Tag Database - Salmon
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; This database is used to evaluate hatchery practices and estimate hatchery contributions. It is used for in-season fisheries management and a variety of research and restoration activities. Fish are tracked from release to return. The database is part of the Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission coast wide database used to monitor salmonoid fish and steelhead as part of the US-Canada fisheries treaty.

metadata.title: Fisheries Information Management System
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; Fisheries Information Management System (FIMS) is a prototype computer system that links data sets routinely used by fisheries managers. This system is a relational data base structure. The purpose of this data set is to provide scientists and fisheries access to public information that will aid them in forming their fisheries plans. The relational database structure uses ORACLE programming. Output products include tables, statistical presentation and graphics. This data is portable to a GIS system to include ARC/INFO and MAP/INFO. Datasets included in FIM are NMFS weekly processor reports, NMFS survey data, NMFS observer data, NMFS FOCI data (oceanographic/climate), ADF&G CFEC fish ticket data, IPHC catch data, IPHC tagging studies, NMML sea lion data, regulatory data, sea surface temperature, bathymetry data, coastline data.

metadata.title: Stocking Records - State Hatcheries
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; This historical database records the numbers of fish stocked in any location around the state supplementing the sport and commercial fisheries. Data covers 1966 to the present although the older data tends to be less reliable. Information is included for all species which FRED stocks and is limited to only those stockings by hatcheries owned by the state. This database ties into the Coded Wire Tag Database of the ADF&G Commercial Management and Development Division.

metadata.title: Glaciers
metadata.description: Data Type: Freshwater Systems;  Statewide glaciers were assembled from seventeen files in the USGS 1:2,000,000 Digital Line Graphs (DLG) dataset by using reselect on the MIN attribute. Although none of the DLG line attributes are maintained within the glaciers coverage, the following MIN values were used during the reselect process: 4060 (glacier length <4 km), 4061 (glacier length 4≤10 km), 4062 (glacier length 10≤17 km), 4063 (glacier length 17≤25 km), 4064 (glacier length 25≤37 km), 4065 (glacier length 37≤50 km), and 4066 (glacier length 50+ km).

metadata.title: Hypsography
metadata.description: Data Type: Freshwater Systems;  The Alaska Department of Natural Resources (ADNR) has combined hypsography for several Digital Chart of the World (DCW) titles into one coverage. Some edits to the data were made, which allowed ADNR to label high elevation points and mountain tops from the DCW data. The coverage contains elevation contours at every 1,000 feet. The hypsography used for statewide map products is often depicted as a contour line at every 3,000 feet, which offers visualization of vertical control as it relates to other map features. Written permission to include these data as part of the ADNR digital basemap has been received from Environmental Systems Research Institute (ESRI).

metadata.title: 97-33 Overview of the Togiak Herring Sac Roe and Spawn-on-Kelp Fisheries, Bristol Bay, Alaska.  Thomas E. Brookover, James B. Browning and Katherine A. Rowell.  October  1997.  19 pp.
metadata.description: Includes (but are not limited to:) (1) Alaska Board of Fisheries and Fishery Management council reports (2) Season summaries (3) White papers (4) management plans (5) annual test fish results (6) legislative reports (7) forecast (8) area management reports (9) annual shellfish surveys (10) some annual U.S./Canada;  and since the 1993, the following studies have been published in this series:  (11) Salmon abundance, catch and escapements studies (12) annual smolt reports (13) tagging studies and (14) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc..
metadata.notes:
Purpose: This series is primarily informational, serving to: (1) promote intradepartmental exchange of information and (2) meet ad hoc reporting functions of the department to other agencies, governmental and regulatory bodies, the fishing industry and the public.  Reports in this series may achieve original observations (raw data) or contain preliminary or incomplete data.  These reports do not receive full editorial and peer review.  Reports may be highly individualized.

metadata.title: Community Profile Database
metadata.description: Data Type: Infrastructure;  The Community Profile Database has been designed to serve as a principal reference source for recent, reliable, summary information about the subsistence uses within the economies of rural Alaskan communities. The database also provides summary information on the commercial-wage sector of a community's economy, recognizing that subsistence uses are part of a mixed subsistence-cash economy in rural Alaska communities. In addition, the database contains information on community demography and community geographic location relative to fish and game management areas, census areas and federal conservation land units. The Community Profile database exists in two forms: (1) a printed database catalog in 6 volumes, and (2) a computerized database system, housed at regional offices of the Division of Subsistence.

metadata.title: Alaska Mammal Collection
metadata.description: Data Type: Mammals;  The Mammal Collection database contains records for 34,000 University of Alaska Museum specimens, most of which are from Alaska. Data include the kinds of information typically associated  with museum specimens, i.e. taxonomic identity, locality, date, measurements, reproductive condition etc. The format of this data is compatible with the Network for Information Retrieval in Mammalogy. This database is intended to support and facilitate use of the Mammal Collection, not as a substitute for specimen-based-research. Therefore, citation of specimen data implies that the researcher has examined the specimens.

metadata.title: ADF&G (Alaska Department of Fish & Game) 1989 Bristol Bay Management Area Annual Management Report 1988.  Alaska Department of Fish & Game, Division of Commercial Fisheries, Regional Information report 4D89-09, Anchorage.
metadata.description: Annual management report includes a description of the management area and an overview of the fishery.  The commercial salmon fishery section includes information on run strength indicators, economics and market production, run and harvest performance by species and a season summary by fishing district.  The subsistence salmon fishery section, provides a discuss of regulations, in season management permit system and harvest.  The herring fishery section outlines stock assessment methods, predicts an overview of Bering sac roe, spawn on kelp, capelin and rainbow smelt fisheries, gives a season summary by fisheries and evaluates exploitation rates of ex-vessel values.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Annual summary of what happened in the commercial and subsistence salmon fisheries and the herring fishery in the Bristol Bay area

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Annually

metadata.title: Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   AVHRR data is collected from NOAA's Polar Orbiting Environmental satellites. AVHRR is a broad-band, 4 or 5 channel (depending on the model) scanner, sensing in the visible, near-infrared and thermal  infrared portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. The average full-resolution instantaneous field-of-view of 1.4 milliradians yields a ground resolution of approximately 1.1 km at the satellite nadir from the nominal orbit altitude of 833 km. Each scan of 2048 pixels generates a raster over 2400 km (1500 miles) across, and the scanning rate is 360 scans per minute. There are approximately 25,000 images of the state of Alaska and adjacent waters in the AVHRR archive at the University of Alaska Fairbanks Geodata Center. Data in the archive dates back to 1974 from the polar orbiting satellites NOAA 2 - 12. Each image has a resolution of 1.1 km. From 1974 to January 1988, most of the imagery  is photographic (transparency) format. Both infrared and visible band data are available. Because of an internal need for near-real-time (daily) satellite imagery, the GeoData Center archived 8-bit digital  field data from the Gilmore Tracking Station on 8-mm high density tapes from 1989 through 1991. There are over 1000 digital images available in this collection (bands 1, 2, and 4). The GeoData center has hard-copy photos from 1974 to 1988, archived data from 1988 to the present is in the form of a facsimile copy. The EROS Data Center (EDC) implemented an AVHRR Data Acquisition and Processing System (ADAPS), in May 1987. Under a current agreement between NOAA and the U.S. Geological Survey, Federal agencies may acquire ADAPS geo-registered and other derivative/enhanced AVHRR data from the EROS Data Center. AVHRR Level 1b data are available from NOAA.

metadata.title: Alaska (VHRR) Twice-Monthly Composites
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;  Alaska AVHRR Data Set is comprised of twice-monthly maximum Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) composites created from daily NOAA-11 satellite observations. The goal of the Alaska AVHRR project is to compile a comprehensive time series data set of calibrated, georegistered daily observations and twice monthly maximum NDVI composites for each annual growing season. This data set has applications for environmental monitoring and assessing impacts of global climate change. The NDVI composites include ten bands of information: AVHRR channels 1-5, maximum NDVI, satellite zenith, solar zenith, and relative azimuth. The daily observations, bands 1-9, have been calibrated to reflectance, scaled to byte data, and geometrically registered to the Albers Equal-Area Conic map projection. The tenth band is a pointer to identify the date and scene ID of the source daily observation (scene) for each pixel. All image processing was conducted using the Land Analysis System (LAS) software. Often when displaying data covering large areas, such as AVHRR data, it is beneficial to include an overlay of familiar linework as a location aid, or a mask to derive statistical data for regions. All of the line work images represent lines in raster format as 1 km cells and the strata are represented as polygons registered to the AVHRR data. The line work and raster polygon data sets include are the international boundaries, Alaskan roads and Trans-Alaska Pipeline, and a raster polygon mask of the State borders. The EROS Data Center standard product is a set of multiple CD-ROM.

metadata.title: Landsat Mosaics for Alaska
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   A series of 143 individual MSS Landsat satellite images pieced together to show the state of Alaska. These images are false-color mosaics showing two visible and two infrared data bands. The imagery is available in a choice of formats and prices, based on two photo-reproduction techniques. The first and higher quality product is made from the original mosaic by contact printing. The second method copies and reduces the products made by the first method. These copies are slightly lower in quality and greatly reduced in price. Hardcopy prints and 35mm slides only media available. This series is intended for general use by the public and scientists investigating minerals, geologic features and other natural features of Alaska.

metadata.title: Multispectral Scanner (MSS) Landsat Data
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   A MSS sensor has flown on all five of the Landsats. The first satellite in the Earth Resources Technology Satellite (ERTS) program was launched July 23, 1972. A second satellite followed on January 22, 1975. At that time the program was redesignated as the Landsat program to emphasize its primary area of interest, land resources. The mission of Landsat is to provide for repetitive acquisition of high resolution multispectral data of the earth's surface on a global basis. Landsat data is available from the U.S. EROS Data 7/16/82 with Landsat 5 following on 3/1/84. Paths 57-68 and Rows 17-20 cover Prince William Sound Copper River Region and Glacier Bay Ecosystem Initiative  Areas. MSS data is collected at low resolution, about 80x60 meters on the ground. Intended use by private commercial organizations, public agencies, and governmental organizations around the world for urban and regional planning, environmental monitoring, conservation, mineral exploration, and many other applications. Landsat 1 was launched 7/23/72 and deactivated 1/6/78; 2 was launched 1/22/75 and deactivated 2/25/82; 3 was launched 3/5/78 and deactivated 3/31/83; 4 was launched 7/16/82 and 5 on 3/1/84. Both Landsat 4 and 5 are still active and carry both MSS and Thematic Mapper. MSS sensor responds to earth reflected sunlight in four spectral bands. There is an additional thermal infrared band, band 8. MSS data available through USGS, EROS data center and Geodata Center, University of Alaska Fairbanks Geophysical Institute, which has 14,000 MSS images.

metadata.title: Spot High Resolution Visible Data

creators.name: (SPOT), Satellite Pour l'Ovservation de la Terre

metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   The French Earth Observation Satellite, SPOT, produces digital satellite imagery with the highest spatial resolution that is commercially available. Panchromatic (black and white) imagery has a resolution of 10x10 meters, and is commonly used for detailed mapping, feature identification, change detection, and updating of vector files. Multispectral imagery (visible and infrared) has a resolution of 20x20 meters and is used for land use and land cover mapping and natural resource studies. SPOT Image offers its digital ortho-imagery in standard 7.5, 15, and 30 minute map frames.

metadata.title: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR)
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   The data set consists of European Remote Sensing Satellite #1 (ERS)-1 and Japanese Earth Resource Satellite (JERS)-1 SAR data acquired by the ASF operated by the Geophysical Institute of University of Alaska Fairbanks. Data within the station mask of ASF, approximated by a 3000 km radius circle centered on Fairbanks has been acquired since September 1991 for ERS and May 1992 for JERS. Approval by NASA or ESA is required to obtain the data. Please contact ASF user services to become a NASA approved investigator. A variety of products are available on a variety of photographic and digital media. Available products include: *Full-res images are 4-look SAR images with 30 m resolution and 12.5 m pixel spacing over a 100 km x 100 km area. These are 8192 pixel 8192 pixel by 8 bit (64MB) images. The data is corrected to the GEM06 geoid model. *Low-res images are produced 8x8 averaging the full-res data. The resulting image is 1024x1024 pixels x8 bits (1 MB). *Geocoded images are produced from either a full-res or lo-res image upon request. Geocoded  images have been processed so they align with the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) or Polar-Stereographic (PS) map projections. Projection attributes and the center latitude and longitude used for processing can be set by the user. *Complex images, created on request, are 1-look data with approximately 10 resolution covering an area of 30x50 km. Data is formatted as 12,888 pixel x 2048 pixel x 32 bit complex integer (16I, 16Q-~100MB). The data contains backscatter amplitude and phase useful for interferometry studies of topography and feature motion. *Computer compatible signal data is spacecraft signal data represented as complex integers in byte aligned 8 bit bytes. Only 5 bits of each byte is significant. Each file is ~160 MB. The user must perform their own signal correlation.

metadata.title: Thematic Mapper (TM) Landsat Data
metadata.description: Data Type: Remotely Sensed Data;   A TM instrument is flown on Landsat 4 and 5, the last two of the five Landsats. Both satellite's TM radiometers acquire day and night data which are systematically corrected during processing. The standard digital data product is in a band sequential (BSQ) FAST format. Landsat 4 and 5's TM mechanical scanning radiometers operate in 7 channels of the electromagnetic spectrum (band 1 spectral range is .45-.52 micometers, band 2 is .52-.60, band 3 is .63-.69, band 4 is .76-.90, band 5 is 1.55-1.75, band 6 is 10.40-12.50, and band 7 is 2.08-2.35). Six reflective bands are blue, green, red, and near infrared. Two shortwave infrared bands and a band measuring emitted energy 10.4 to 12.5 micrometers and has 120 meter ground resolution. Landsat 4 was launched 7/16/82 with Landsat 5 following on 3/1/84. Paths 57-68 and Rows 17-20 cover Prince William Sound Copper River Region and Glacier Bay Ecosystem Initiative Areas.

metadata.title: Alaska Biological Conservation Database
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  The Alaska Biological Conservation Database (BCD) is part of a standardized network among all fifty states, five Canadian Provinces, and eleven countries that provide information on population numbers, distribution, geography, ecology, rarity ranking and protection status for rare and sensitive plant and animal species, plant communities, and critical habitats. This database is a relational database management system application that contains many linked databases of which three are separate databases with a spatial component. These databases are the element occurrence database, the site database and the managed area database. Of these three data sets only the Element occurrence database has been automated in ARC/INFO GIS format to date.

metadata.title: ADF&G 1990 Bristol Bay Management Area Annual Management Report 1989.  Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Division of Commercial Fisheries, Regional Information Report 2K90-03, Anchorage
metadata.description: Annual management report includes a description of the management area and an overview of the fishery.  The commercial salmon fishery section includes information on run strength indicators, economics and market production, run and harvest performance by species and a season summary by fishing district.  The subsistence salmon fishery section, provides a discuss of regulations, in season management permit system and harvest.  The herring fishery section outlines stock assessment methods, predicts an overview of Bering sac roe, spawn on kelp, capelin and rainbow smelt fisheries, gives a season summary by fisheries and evaluates exploitation rates of ex-vessel values.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Annual summary of what happened in the commercial and subsistence salmon fisheries and the herring fishery in the Bristol Bay area

metadata.title: Alaska Seabird Colony Catalog

creators.name: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Office

metadata.description: Seabird Colony Catalog database is an ongoing synthesis of seabird field survey data geographically separated into eleven regions, region four covers the Gulf of Alaska. This system is primarily a database management system with the ability to portray spatial data to a map. The database has three major data components, species information, colony information and life history information. Some 45 species in 2600 colonies are archived in this database. Species numbers, date, and other information on census method, observer, data quality codes, footnotes, historical data and best estimates, are included for each seabird colony. The database is updated to reflect ongoing field surveys from a variety of contributors and USFWS. Output from the system can be in the form of textual query results, ascii flat files and eventually maps. Database was initially developed using CMAS (Computer Mapping and Analysis System) and ATLAS MAPMAKER on a MacIntosh computer, and has since been ported by USFWS to PC Paradox database format. Output from this database is exported to Atlas GIS for map generation. The intended use of this database is to provide information to the state decision making process for development in the coastal zone and for emergency response, and regional scale analysis of distribution patterns for biogeographic investigation.
metadata.notes:

metadata.title: Marbled and Kittlitze Murrelet Survey's
metadata.description: Data Type: Birds;   A cooperative effort between Michael McAllister, Wildland Resource Enterprises, C.J. Ralph, US Forest Service Redwood Science Laboratory, Arcada, CA. and John Piatt, National Biological Service, Anchorage, Alaska. Transects were recorded from the bridge of a 58 foot Seine Vessel while traveling between and during salmon and herring fisheries: Alexander Archipelago, Prince William Sound, Kenai Peninsula, Alaska Peninsula, and Bristol Bay. The majority of transects are near shore regions of the Gulf of Alaska. Absolute counts, behavior, flyways, fishholding, fledged young, and molt data are recorded throughout surveys. Additional relative distribution records were recorded for all bird species and migratory counts. The most extensive records are from northern Southeast Alaska. Latitude and Longitudes were recorded on NOAA National Ocean Service Charts.

metadata.description: Annual management report includes a description of the management area and an overview of the fishery.  The commercial salmon fishery section includes information on run strength indicators, economics and market production, run and harvest performance by species and a season summary by fishing district.  The subsistence salmon fishery section, provides a discuss of regulations, in season management permit system and harvest.  The herring fishery section outlines stock assessment methods, predicts an overview of Bering sac roe, spawn on kelp, capelin and rainbow smelt fisheries, gives a season summary by fisheries and evaluates exploitation rates of ex-vessel values.

metadata.title: Steller Sea Lion Locations
metadata.description: Data Type: Mammals;   National Marine Fisheries, Marine Mammal Lab in cooperation with the Alaska Department of Fish and Game collects and catalogs location data for sea lion rookeries and haulouts and critical habitats and collects associated data pertaining to ongoing research on population study, wintering habitats, annual pup counts, and studies related to rookeries, behavior, tagging, reproduction, and feeding Satellite radio telemetry data is also collected in the eastern Gulf of Alaska, at Cape St. Elias, Kodiak and in Southeast Alaska. A variety of systems such as ARC/INFO and CAMRIS (Computer Aided Mapping and Resources Inventory System) and various database systems have been used to store and analyze this data over time. As of 1994, the Alaska Department of Fish and Game has launched an effort to begin using ARC/INFO to analyze the distribution and abundance data to evaluate sea lion critical habitats. This data is the GIS application of the same data set in National Marine Fisheries, Marine Fisheries Lab, metadata record #070.

metadata.description: Data Type: Mammals;   The movements of telemetered marine mammals in Alaskan waters are tracked through the use of CAMRIS (Computer Aided Mapping and Resource Inventory System), a small GIS system. This dataset stores shorelines, bathymetry, animal locations and tracks. Sea surface temperature and ice edge formation is also incorporated. This system contains data from the equator to the north pole. This system incorporates animals tagged using the ARGOS radiotags.

metadata.title: NATIONAL OCEAN SURVEY AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY
metadata.description: Data Type: Oceans/Coasts;   Aerial photography for coastal areas of Alaska. These photos include flights over areas of Prince William Sound during the summers of 1976 and 1977 for the Outer Continental Shelf Environment Assessment Program at altitudes of 5,000 to 18,400. Indexes showing the exact flight lines are available. The photographs are indexed on 1:250,000-scale base maps, with the center position of each individual exposure indicated by a dot. The first and last exposure of a line, along with several in between, are labeled. Paper copies of these indexes are available for $3.00 each. For Prince William Sound consult indexes C-38 to C-45, and for Glacier Bay area consult indexes F-3 to F-9. The indexes may be ordered from NOAA, National Ocean Service (301) 713-2692, or indexes are available for viewing at the Anchorage, Alaska NOAA office, 222 West 7th Ave, (907) 271-5040.

metadata.title: Historic Sea Surface Temperature 1985-90
metadata.description: Data Type: Oceans/Coasts;   A data set of AVHRR derived sea surface temperature for the SEA study area. This project is not yet complete. The aim of the project is to develop an annual spring through summer time-series of ocean temperatures for 1985-1990. These layers are being produced using the same protocols as that being used by Dr. David Eslinger and his students at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) to process daily sea surface temperature under another project. Eventually, they hope to integrate the two data sets into one uninterrupted series.
